subject: RE: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Certainly. For example you should probably have Acceptance Tests. ... Who said that the only alternative to not using JTest was to use no automated testing

> >There is of course at least a third option: uninstall JTest
> >and ship tested, optimal code nevertheless... ;-)
>
> While unit tests are a Very Good Thing(tm) they are not 100%
> of the testing that should be performed on a body of code.

Certainly. For example you should probably have Acceptance Tests.

> So, I know that I will be using a combination of Jtest and
> Junit for a long time to come. If you write optimal code
> without the need for automated testing tools, then I salute you! :-)

Who said that the only alternative to not using JTest was to use no
automated testing tool at all?

BTW, are you developing test-first?


> >> I would actually interpret these exceptions as an indication
> >of some extra guard conditions and more defensive programming
> >needed within the tested code. If a piece of called code
> >cannot handle unexpected inputs, then the fault lies with the
> >code and not the inputs. :-)
> >
> >I disagree. If the input violates a precondition, the fault
> >lies with the input, by definition.
>
> I wholeheartedly disagree with you. It makes no difference
> what your "contract" is between a piece of software and it's
> callers, if the software doesn't check it's own inputs then
> it is at fault.

Mhh, I wasn't talking about the input to the software, but about the
input from internal components to internal components. Would you agree
that precondition possibly isn't that critical there?

Regards, Ilja
